lesson.title: ARIMA Models
lesson.summary: In this lesson you’ll learn how to build and use ARIMA models. ARIMA stands for autoregressive, integrated, moving average, which are the inputs for ARIMA models.

atoms.title: More Info
atoms.text: For some additional reading about ARIMA models, check out [this overview](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/a/autoregressive-integrated-moving-average-arima.asp) from Investopedia.

atoms.title: Note
atoms.text:
### Refresher on Correlation and Variance

In case you need a brief refresher, follow these links to read a bit more about [correlation](https://www.mathsisfun.com/data/correlation.html) and [variance](http://www.mathsisfun.com/data/standard-deviation.html).

atoms.title: Quiz Intro
atoms.text:
## Identifying Stationary Data

For each time series plot below, indicate whether the time series is stationary or non-stationary.

question.prompt: Indicate whether the time series below is stationary or non-stationary.
Indicate whether the time series below is stationary or non-stationary.
Indicate whether the time series below is stationary or non-stationary.
Indicate whether the time series below is stationary or non-stationary.

atoms.title: Differencing
atoms.text:
## Differencing
Differencing is a method of transforming a non-stationary time series to a stationary one. This is an important step in preparing data to be used in an ARIMA model. Let’s go through an example to understand differencing. 

### Differencing Example
Imagine a toothbrush manufacturer is trying to predict demand in order to make decisions about production. As you’d imagine, toothbrush sales are not subject to much seasonality. Take a look at the video below to see how you would manually difference a time series in a spreadsheet.

atoms.title: Note
atoms.text:
### Differencing and the **I** Term of ARIMA 
The number of times of differencing needed to render the series stationary will be the differenced I(d) term in our ARIMA model.

The best way to determine whether or not the series is sufficiently differenced is to plot the differenced series and check to see if there is a constant mean and variance.

atoms.title: Quiz
atoms.text:
## Differencing a Time Series

Using the **Weekly Sales Differencing** file, calculate the first and second difference of the time series.

question.prompt: What's the first difference on the first Week 47?
What's the second difference on the first Week 16?

atoms.title: Solution
atoms.text:
# Differencing in Excel

Take a look at the video for how to calculate the first and second difference. Also, there's a solution Excel file at the bottom of the page for your reference.

atoms.title: Correction
atoms.text:
### Minor Correction

At around 2:00, Tony mentions that the ACF plot points towards using an AR(1) model because "after we stationarized the dataset through differencing, there was positive autocorrelation at lag-1 and the spikes decay towards 0."

The correct sentence is, "Analyzing the plot we just looked at, we have a suggestion of an AR(1) model because after we stationarized the dataset through differencing, there was positive autocorrelation at lag-1 and then the autocorrelation cuts off to zero.

atoms.title: Note
atoms.text:
### More on Partial Autocorrelation

If you want to read more and dig into the math behind calculating partial autocorrelation, follow [this link](https://onlinecourses.science.psu.edu/stat510/lesson/2/2.2) or [this one](https://machinelearningmastery.com/gentle-introduction-autocorrelation-partial-autocorrelation/#:~:text=A%20partial%20autocorrelation%20is%20a,relationships%20of%20intervening%20observations%20removed.).

atoms.title: Workflow Steps
atoms.text:
### Workflow Steps

- Use the “Input” tool to import the TB Sales data
- Connect a “TS Plot” tool to the data stream and configure it:
    - Select “Toothbrush Sales” as the target field
    - Set the target field frequency to “monthly”
    - Set the plot type to “time series plot”
- Add a “Browse” tool to the I output of the TS Plot tool, and run the workflow

atoms.title: Reviewing ACF and PACF Plots
atoms.text:
## Reviewing ACF and PACF Plots

Remember you should always review the ACF and PACF of *differenced* series when making judgements on how many AR and MA terms to include.

atoms.title: Quiz Intro
atoms.text:
## Interpreting ACF and PACF Plots

For each of the ACF and PACF plots below, determine the number of terms for the AR and MA components to include in the ARIMA model.

question.prompt: How many AR and MA terms should be included for the time series with the ACF and PACF plots below?
How many AR and MA terms should be included for the time series with the ACF and PACF plots below?

atoms.title: Note
atoms.text:
## Still need help selecting AR and MA terms?

If after watching the videos you'd still like to understand a little better, [this webpage](http://people.duke.edu/~rnau/411arim3.htm) created by Duke University has a pretty explanation. The first half of the page is most relevant, and only takes about 5-10 minutes to read.

atoms.title: Untitled
atoms.text: In the latest version of Alteryx the TS Plot tool requires you to filter out any null values for the target field before the TS Plot tool. You can download the image instructions of what you will need to add here: [Instructions](https://s3.amazonaws.com/video.udacity-data.com/topher/2018/December/5c09aa0f_ts-plot-tool-error-debugging/ts-plot-tool-error-debugging.pdf)

atoms.title: Workflow Steps Part 1
atoms.text:
### Workflow Steps Part 1

- Use the “Input” tool to import the Bookings data
- Connect a “Multi-Row Formula” tool to the data stream and configure it:
    - Create a new output field called “Seasonal Difference,” with output type “double”
    - Set the number of rows to 12
    - Set the value for rows that do not exist to NULL
    - Set the expression to “bookings - row - 12: bookings”
- Add a “Filter” tool to filter for “seasonal difference is not null”
- Connect a “TS Plot” tool to the T output of the filter and configure it:
    - Select “Seasonal Difference” as the target field
    - Set the target field frequency to “monthly”
    - Set the plot type to “time series plot”
- Add a “Browse” tool to the I output of the TS Plot tool, and run the workflow

atoms.title: Workflow Steps Part 2
atoms.text:
### Workflow Steps Part 2

- Connect a second “Multi-row Formula” tool to the first and configure it:
    - Create a new field called “S First Difference” and set it to type “double”
    - Set NULL for values that don’t exist
    - Set the expression to “seasonal difference - row - 1: seasonal difference”
- Add a “Filter” tool to filter for “S first difference is not null”
- Connect a “TS Plot” tool to the T output of the filter and configure it:
    - Select “S First Difference” as the target field
    - Set the target field frequency to “monthly”
    - Set the plot type to “time series plot”
- Add a “Browse” tool to the I output of the TS Plot tool, and run the workflow

atoms.title: Q1
atoms.text:
Calculating Seasonal Differencing

Using the Quarterly Sales file, calculate the seasonal difference of the time series.

question.prompt: What is the seasonal difference of period 4Q4?

atoms.title: note
atoms.text:
## Reviewing ACF and PACF Plots

Remember you should always review the ACF and PACF of *differenced* series when making judgements on how many AR and MA terms to include.

atoms.title: Workflow Steps
atoms.text:
### Workflow Steps

- Continuing in the same workflow from the Seasonal Differencing example, connect a “Record ID” tool to the input data
- Add a “Filter” tool and filter for “record ID <= 114,” to create a holdout sample
- Connect an “ARIMA” tool to the T output of the filter and configure it:
    - Name the model ARIMA
    - Select “Bookings” as the target field, and set the target field frequency to “monthly”
    - In the “model customization” tab, select “completely user specified model” and configure the terms:
    - Set p to 0 and set d and q to 1
    - Set P to 0 and set D and Q to 1
    - In the “other options” tab, set the series start year to 2006 and the number of periods to include in the forecast to 6
- Copy-paste the ARIMA tool, give the new one the name “ARIMA_MA2,” and connect it to the T output of the record ID filter
    - In the new tool, change the value of Q to 2
- Add a “Browse” tool to the R output of each ARIMA tool, and run the workflow

atoms.title: Quiz Intro
atoms.text:
Build Your First ARIMA Model

Now's you chance to get some practice. You'll now build your first ARIMA model using the Champagne Sales dataset, which is the same dataset you used to build your ETS model. Use the steps below to guide you. (HINT: Like the *ETS* tool, the *ARIMA* tool has an auto setting under the *model customization* tab. You can check your manual model and what the auto setting would give you.) * **Step 1 - Check stationarity:** If a time series has a trend or seasonality component, it must be made stationary before we can use ARIMA to forecast. Use the *TS Plot* tool to see if the time series is stationary. * **Step 2 - Difference:** If the time series is not stationary, it needs to be stationarized through differencing. Take the first difference, then check for stationarity. Take as many differences as it takes. Make sure you check seasonal differencing as well. * ** Step 3 - Filter out a validation sample:** This will be used to validate how accurate our model is. Use the last 6 periods as the validation sample. * ** Step 4 - Select AR and MA terms:** Use the ACF and PACF to decide whether to include an AR term(s), MA term(s), or both. * ** Step 5 - Build the model:** Build the model and set the number of periods to forecast to 6. * ** Step 6 - Validate model:** Compare the predicted values to the actuals in the validation sample.

question.prompt: Using an ARIMA(1,0,0)(1,1,0)12 model, what is the projected sales value in the final period.

atoms.title: Untitled
atoms.text: ## If you are getting an error that states: #### ARIMA: Error in searchDir(dbDir, lang) : expecting a string This issue seems to arise when the language registry file is missing, so I have attached a zipped folder with 3 files (one for each language supported in Alteryx) that should replace these registry files. Download the zipped folder and open it https://s3.amazonaws.com/video.udacity-data.com/topher/2018/February/5a8e085d_language-key/language-key.zip 1. Make sure you choose the language they would prefer (English, German, French) and follows these steps: 2. Double-click on the file for your preferred language 3. The use will see this screen: Click "OK" NOTE 1: This file will determine the language that Alteryx uses, so make sure the user chooses the correct language. NOTE 2: The user may need admin access to run these files.

atoms.title: Intro to Solution
atoms.text:
## Building Your First ARIMA Model

**Step 1 - Check stationarity:** First thing to do is to visualize the data with a *TS Plot*. Connect a browse tool to the **I** output node and take a look at the output. You can see some seasonality and perhaps some trend as well.

atoms.title: S2
atoms.text: **Step 2 - Difference:** Let's start with a seasonal difference and observe the resulting plot. To take the seasonal difference, you use a *Multi-Row Formula* tool and use the formula **[Champagne Sales] - [Row-12:Champagne Sales]**. Attach a browse tool and look at the plot. It looks like the seasonal differencing was enough to make the time series stationary!

atoms.title: L
atoms.text: ** Step 3 - Filter out a validation sample:** This is done the same was it was done with the ETS model. Attach a *Record ID* and *Filter* tools to the *Data Input* tool and filter out the last 6 periods.

atoms.title: S4
atoms.text:
** Step 4 - Select AR and MA terms:** Let's take a look at the ACF and PACF of the seasonally differenced dataset. There appears to be significant positive autocorrelation at periods 1 and 13. The positive autocorrelation points towards AR terms, so I'd suggest starting with one AR term for both the seasonal and non-seasonal parts of the ARIMA model for: 

#### ARIMA(1,0,0)(1,1,0)12

Remember, selecting these terms manually generally means choosing several models and comparing them against a validation sample. In our case, we'll just build out one manual model for practice, then use the auto settings to have the tool choose the best model for us.

atoms.title: S5
atoms.text: ** Step 5 - Build the model:** Build the model using the *ARIMA* tool and set the number of periods to forecast to 6. Attach a browse tool to the **I** output node. After running the model, you can see the forecast of the last six periods. The forecast of the final period is 13,366.

atoms.title: S6
atoms.text: ** Step 6 - Validate model:** Compare the predicted values to the actuals in the validation sample using the *TS Compare* tool. For the final period, the ARIMA model forecasted  13,366 vs the actual of 12,670.

atoms.title: Untitled
atoms.text: # Learning Summary The purpose of this learning summary is to provide the high level steps to build and use ARIMA models to make a business decision. Along the side are suggested Alteryx tools to use while implementing the model.

## Glossary

**ARIMA model:** autoregressive integrated moving average model, can be seasonal or non-seasonal

**Autocorrelation:** the degree to which a time series is correlated with its own past values

**Autocorrelation function (ACF) plot:** a plot that shows the correlation of a time series with itself, lagged by X time units

**Autoregressive (AR) component:** acts like a linear regression model, used to forecast a variable based on a combination of past values of that variable

**Differencing:** the process by which a time series is made stationary

**Integrated (I) component:** the amount of differencing required to stationarize a time series

**Moving average (MA) component:** used if a time series has random jumps which affect two or more consecutive periods

**Partial autocorrelation:** correlation between two variables controlling for the values of another set of variables

**Seasonal difference:** a series of changes from one season to the next

**Stationarity:** when a time series has a constant mean and variance over time
